item.title: Evolving your RESTful APIs, a step-by-step approach
item.description: Designing an intuitive, user-friendly RESTful API is a tough job. It might already be a massive task if it’s your first attempt. Planning for the lifecycle management of your API is likely to be an afterthought. But it’s possible anyway: in this post, I’d like to propose a no-nonsense approach to evolving your APIs, even if it was not planned. The initial situation Let’s consider a sample application that says 'Hello' when using it. > curl http://org.apisix/hello Hello world > curl
item.author: (Nicolas Fränkel)

item.title: pSYoniK - Software, Hardware and Tech
item.description: Every online purchase nowadays requires an email address. Every organisation, company, form or review left online asks for your email address. This dark-pattern has become so ubiquitous that it has domesticated us and we gleefully provide it to anyone. However, just because someone asks for your email address, it doesn’t mean that they can protect it and along with it, access to a host of other accounts you might have. With this in mind, allow me to detail some of these risks as well as provide ways of mitigating them.
